awd_titl_txt: Modular biochemical networks of maize anti-pathogen defense defined by integrating synthetic biochemistry, genetics and physiological function
awd_abstract_narration:
Crop biochemical defense mechanisms effective against most pests and diseases are essential to agricultural productivity. The natural genetic diversity among individual cultivars provides unique, but underutilized, layers of stress resilience. Maize (Zea mays) is the agronomically most important U.S. crop and among the most genetically diverse. Conceptually parallel to the sticky sap promoting wound healing in pine trees, maize is protected by inducible chemicals, termed diterpenoids, that act as antibiotics to suppress pest attack and disease. Empirically, maize plants lacking diterpenoid defenses display dramatic increases in fungal disease damage. The current project unveils mechanisms of crop stress resilience by defining the formation and diverse bioactivities underlying maize diterpenoid defenses. Variable chemical diversity between established inbred lines will be leveraged to identify diterpenoid-biosynthetic genes and enzyme functions using state-of-the-art genetic mapping and biochemical technologies. Integrating a systematic array of computational, wet-lab and field-based approaches will discover the biosynthetic machinery, chemical structures, and ecological importance of maize diterpenoids. These deliverables will enable new strategies for enhancing crop protection in the face of pressing needs for improving agricultural productivity. The activation of diterpenoid synthesis by readily available food-grade fungi will be developed as an educational tool in high schools to foster intellectual curiosity about plant immune responses, their agricultural use, and the importance of biochemicals to humans. The project will positively impact society by discovering and harnessing biochemical crop defenses and teaching modern STEM concepts and technologies through implementing high school Lesson Study Modules using our integrated approach.

Complex combinations of biotic and abiotic stressors can overcome crop defenses and promote yield losses. As the dominant global grain crop, maize (Zea mays) contains unique and largely unresolved specialized diterpenoid metabolites that contribute to plant resilience by conferring quantitative protection against pathogens. A foundational understanding and agricultural application of molecular mechanisms underlying maize biochemical networks will be essential to further optimize crop resilience. This collaborative project will leverage complementary genetic, biochemical and ecological approaches to gain a precise mechanistic knowledge of specialized metabolites governing maize disease resistance. Integrating functional genomics, metabolomics, forward genetics, DNA synthesis, and combinatorial in vitro and in vivo protein biochemical approaches will enable rapid pathway discovery to elucidate maize-specific diterpenoid-metabolic networks. Parallel generation and analysis of maize mutants in defined pathway nodes will unravel the interrelations between fungal-elicited diterpenoid biosynthesis and pathogen resistance in planta. In tandem, in vitro anti-fungal bioassays of purified diterpenoids with a range of maize pathogens will illuminate the structure-function relationships underlying diterpenoid bioactivity. The cross-disciplinary nature of this project provides an excellent framework for training postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate students, and will be leveraged to connect the project team with local high school teachers for developing Lesson Study Modules as a platform to engage high school students in cross-cutting principles underlying plant-pathogen interactions. To promote research and education at the confluence of maize-microbe interactions and agricultural innovation, knowledge, resources such as enzyme/metabolite catalogs, mutant lines, and training modules arising from this work will be broadly shared with the scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

 Much like human languages, plants use complex blends of small biochemicals to communicate with other organisms, protect against diseases and respond to environmental stresses. Understanding, how these chemicals are made and mediate plant interactions with their biotic and abiotic environment is a fundamental question in biology with direct applications in both agricultural and natural product engineering bioeconomies. To fully undercover how corn, a major U.S. food, feed and biofuel crop, deploys chemical defenses against critical microbial diseases we pursued integrated systems biology and biochemical approaches. In a highly collaborative NSF project, we elucidated multiple crop specific antibiotic biosynthetic pathways, demonstrated roles in disease resistance and identified significant interactions with plant growth and development. Collaborative work of the Schmelz (UC San Diego) and Zerbe (UC Davis) laboratories generated several groundbreaking discoveries in understanding plant disease resistance mechanisms, identified critical control points, nodes for manipulation, provided large gene/enzyme collections for crop breeding and natural product engineering. Our efforts are detailed in the publication of 12 peer-reviewed papers (including Nature Plants) and have resulted in the training of many diverse young scientists from undergraduate to the postdoctoral levels.

 

MAJOR SCIENTIFIC DISCOVERIES

 Unlike linear assembly line processes, modular plant biochemical defense pathways can share biosynthetic nodes, use diverse substrates and generate complex antibiotic cocktails.

 By investigating biochemical defenses that underly fungal disease resistance in corn, we discovered that multiple related enzymes collectively utilize diverse substrates from different pathways to generate a large pool of bioactive products. Integrating extensive genomic, genetic and biochemical studies we demonstrated, for the first time, clear evidence for a “biosynthetic hourglass” pathway. At least 4 different antibiotic pathways converge on a node of highly related co-expressed biosynthetic enzymes resulting in diverse chemical structures and downstream modifications that yield distinct bioactivities. Our funding enabled us to pursue “modular biochemical networks” and we discovered that protective pathways in living plants can be even more modular, interactive and interconnected than was previously imagined. This knowledge critically informs and enables engineering approaches that can more rapidly predict, tune and ultimately customize critical layers of plant immunity.

 Plant biochemical immune pathways derived from ancient hormone pathways and can feed back on primary processes to promote increased plant growth.

Over activation of plant immunity can stunt growth and contribute to yield losses in the face of increasing environmental and crop disease pressures. By understanding specific gene and enzyme combinations that control biosynthesis of ancient growth hormone pathways and an array of more recently derived defense pathways, we demonstrate that an exchange of pathway intermediates is possible. We then leveraged these discoveries to alter metabolism and push defensive-related precursors back upon hormone biosynthetic pathways to drive positive growth responses. Unlike common growth suppression following immune activation or elevated disease symptoms caused by immune deficiency, we demonstrate an example where precisely targeted immune pathway mutants display significantly increased vigor and growth. The understanding of defined check points that can control, and even uncouple, plant growth and defense tradeoffs represents a significant advance with the long-term potential for controlling crop traits.  

 BROADER IMPACTS

 The Schmelz and Zerbe laboratories have trained over 20 students from the undergraduate to the postdoctoral levels in STEM related fields. This is independent from additional extensive training efforts in undergraduate laboratory coursework. Past graduate students and postdoctoral fellows have been awarded numerous fellowships and successfully secured faculty positions, government research positions or jobs in industry. Notably, one former graduate student was recently appointed as Director of Phenotyping at the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center. Several students who identify as members of underrepresented minorities conducted summer research internships as part of this project. Undergraduate students who received training as part of this project have moved on to medical school, to positions in the biotechnology industry and graduate schools in the Plant Sciences. Collectively trainees from the project team members have added to the STEM workforce which helps fill a critical national need to remain competitive in the global bioeconomy. Undergraduate teaching materials developed in the current project were used train hundreds of students and guided expansive plans for greater teaching initiatives in Metabolomics.
